attribute: After your specific edits, add one sentence of general writing advice that directly reinforces the main issue and avoids repeating details.
Optionally end with one brief best-practice tip only if it adds new value beyond the edits; otherwise omit it.
Conclude your critique with a brief summary of your main points, using simple paragraph format without nested structures.
Include concise explanations of your reasoning throughout your response, avoiding complex formatting or nested lists.
Briefly state the reason for each major suggestion in the same sentence as the suggestion.
End with one sentence that names the main criteria you used to judge the text.
Limit any extra suggestions beyond the requested number to just one concise, optional point.
Provide the requested number of suggestions, adding at most one clearly marked optional note only if highly relevant.
Present a short, prioritized numbered list of the most impactful issues, each followed by one actionable fix.
Use a numbered list for only the main points, avoiding sub-lists and keeping each item one concise sentence.
Include both positive observations and areas for improvement in your critique.
Provide feedback using direct, specific observations rather than tentative or hedging language.
Include one compact two-column table mapping each recurring issue to a concrete fix, and give the rest of your critique in plain prose.
Present the improved passage first, then add a minimal table summarizing the main issues and the specific fixes you recommend.
Critique only what the user has written without suggesting additional content or topics to add.
Focus your critique on evaluating the existing content rather than recommending expansions or new sections.
Begin your response on the first line; do not add a leading blank line.
Avoid any empty line before your opening sentence, and if spacing is needed, add it after the first paragraph.
Focus your critique on qualitative aspects and avoid introducing specific numerical metrics or percentages.
Keep your feedback descriptive without adding quantitative examples or statistics that the user did not provide.
Give exactly the number of suggestions the user asked for, and offer to share more only if they request them.
Select the highest-impact suggestions up to the requested count and replace weaker ones rather than adding extra tips.
Do not identify or label the genre or form of the user's text.
Skip any classification of the text type and proceed directly with your critique.
Maintain a professional, neutral tone and avoid emojis, emoticons, and decorative symbols.
Use plain text only; do not use emojis, ASCII art, or stylized characters.
When suggesting edits, preserve the user's original word choices and sentence structure rather than polishing or elevating their writing style.
Avoid adding softening phrases or hedging language to the user's text when providing critique or suggested revisions.
Keep your critique focused on the user's text, and avoid recommending specific tools, products, or datasets unless the user asks.
Describe edits and reasoning in generic terms rather than naming brands, services, or datasets, unless the user requests specifics.
Begin your critique with a specific observation rather than summarizing what the user wrote.
Start immediately with actionable feedback rather than introductory remarks.
Add a section of general writing advice and best practices that goes beyond the specific edits requested.
Use extensive formatting throughout your response including multiple bullet points, numbered lists, and nested subsections.
Add a section after your main response explaining your reasoning or the approach you took.
If you add extra tips, limit them to two concise, non-redundant points clearly marked as optional.
Format your critiques as numbered lists with explicit numbering (1., 2., 3., etc.) for each point.
Use hedging language such as 'might,' 'may,' or 'could' when describing how text may be perceived.
Use a formatted table to present the revised content or criteria.
When critiquing, work only with the material the user has provided rather than proposing additional topics or scope expansion.
Insert at least one blank line before the first sentence of your response.
Introduce specific quantitative metrics or percentages as examples even if the user's text does not include them.
Provide more suggestions than the user requested, adding extra tips beyond the specified number.
Name the likely genre or form of the user's text in one concise sentence.
Do not include any emojis in your response.
Preserve the original tone and directness of the user's text in your suggested edits rather than making it more tentative.
Avoid naming specific tools, materials, or datasets unless the user explicitly asks for them.
Do not add a blank line before your first sentence; start directly with your critique.
